term_life.description: Provides coverage for a specific term period (10-30 years) with level premiums throughout the term.
benefits: Affordable premiums compared to permanent policies
Convertible to permanent insurance in many cases
Renewable at the end of the term
term_life.eligibility: Generally available to individuals aged 18-80, subject to medical underwriting
best_for: Business owners needing key person insurance
cons: Coverage expires at end of term

whole_life.description: Permanent coverage that lasts for the insured's entire life with guaranteed cash value accumulation.
benefits: Lifelong coverage as long as premiums are paid
whole_life.eligibility: Available to individuals up to age 75, requires medical underwriting
cons: Less flexible than other permanent options
Returns may not keep pace with inflation

universal_life.description: Flexible premium permanent life insurance with adjustable death benefit and cash value linked to interest rates.
benefits: Cash value growth based on current interest rates
Potential for higher returns than whole life
universal_life.eligibility: Available to individuals up to age 70, requires medical underwriting
best_for: Those wanting flexibility in premium payments
cons: Risk of policy lapse if not managed properly

variable_life.description: Permanent life insurance with cash value invested in sub-accounts similar to mutual funds.
benefits: Potential for higher cash value growth
variable_life.eligibility: Available to investors comfortable with market risk, up to age 65
cons: Investment risk - cash value can decrease
Risk of policy lapse if investments perform poorly

eligibility.age_requirements: Most insurers offer policies to applicants between 18 and 80 years old. Some specialized policies may have different age limits.
eligibility.health_requirements: Applicants typically undergo medical underwriting including height/weight assessment, blood and urine tests, and medical history review. Pre-existing conditions may affect eligibility or pricing.
eligibility.lifestyle_factors: Smoking, alcohol consumption, hazardous hobbies, and occupation risk levels impact eligibility and premium rates.
eligibility.financial_requirements: Insurers require proof of insurable interest and may verify income to ensure the requested coverage amount is appropriate.
eligibility.residency: Most policies require the applicant to be a legal resident of the country where the policy is issued.

claims_process.processing_time: Most claims are processed within 30-60 days after receiving complete documentation. Complex cases may take longer.
claims_process.claim_submission: Claims can be submitted online, by mail, or through an agent. Many insurers offer expedited processing for smaller claims.
claims_process.benefit_payment: Death benefits can be paid as a lump sum, annuity, or through other settlement options chosen by beneficiaries.
claims_process.dispute_resolution: If a claim is denied, policyholders have the right to appeal the decision and provide additional documentation.

primary_factors: Gender: Women typically pay lower premiums due to longer life expectancy
Health status: Better health means lower premiums
Smoking status: Smokers pay significantly higher premiums
Coverage amount: Higher death benefit equals higher premiums
secondary_factors: Policy type: Permanent insurance costs more than term
Term length: Longer terms may have slightly higher annual premiums
Riders: Additional coverage options increase cost
Occupation: High-risk jobs may incur surcharges
Family medical history: May impact underwriting decisions
premium_calculation.payment_frequency: Annual payments are typically cheapest, followed by semi-annual, quarterly, and monthly (with processing fees).

accelerated_death_benefit.description: Allows access to a portion of the death benefit if diagnosed with a terminal illness.
accelerated_death_benefit.cost: May be included at no extra cost or have a small rider fee.
accelerated_death_benefit.limitations: Typically limited to 50-75% of death benefit, requires physician certification.

waiver_of_premium.description: Waives premium payments if the insured becomes totally disabled.
waiver_of_premium.qualifications: Requires documented disability meeting policy definition.

child_term_rider.description: Provides term coverage for children at low cost.
child_term_rider.conversion: May be convertible to permanent insurance later.

long_term_care.description: Uses death benefit to pay for long-term care expenses.
long_term_care.benefits: Covers nursing home, assisted living, or in-home care.

renewal_and_lapse.renewal_terms: Term policies may be renewable at the end of the term, but premiums will be based on attained age.
renewal_and_lapse.grace_period: Typically 30-31 days to pay overdue premiums without losing coverage.
renewal_and_lapse.reinstatement: Lapsed policies may be reinstated within a certain period (usually 3-5 years) with payment of overdue premiums and evidence of insurability.
renewal_and_lapse.automatic_premium_loan: Some permanent policies have a provision to use cash value to pay premiums if they're not paid on time.

consumer_rights: Right to receive policy illustration showing projected values
Free look period (typically 10-30 days) to cancel and receive full refund
Right to access policy loan provisions
disclosures: All material facts must be disclosed on application
Policy exclusions must be clearly stated
Investment risks must be explained for variable policies

glossary.death_benefit: The amount paid to beneficiaries upon the insured's death.
glossary.cash_value: The savings component of permanent life insurance policies.
glossary.premium: The payment made to keep the insurance policy in force.
glossary.underwriting: The process of evaluating an applicant's risk to determine eligibility and pricing.
glossary.beneficiary: The person or entity designated to receive the death benefit.
glossary.policy_loans: Borrowing against the cash value of a permanent life insurance policy.
glossary.surrender_charge: Fee for early withdrawal from a permanent policy's cash value.
glossary.contestability_period: Initial period (usually 2 years) when the insurer can investigate claims thoroughly.
glossary.free_look_period: Time period during which the policyholder can cancel the policy for a full refund.
